title: "Unexpected `(` after qualified path" when constructing an otherwise valid path

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: A-parser
labels.description: Area: The parsing of Rust source code to an AST.

labels.name: A-macros
labels.description: Area: All kinds of macros (custom derive, macro_rules!, proc macros, ..)

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Given the following code: https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=23d8fee53f05f5656d51ae3b6525395d

The current output is:

```
error: unexpected `(` after qualified path
  --> src/lib.rs:47:48
   |
47 |                 Err(<$foo as Foo>::Error::Corge(_)) => (),
   |                     ---------------------------^ unexpected `(` after qualified path
   |                     |
   |                     the qualified path
...
72 |     test_foo_impl!(Grault);
   |     ----------------------- in this macro invocation
   |
   = note: this error originates in a macro (in Nightly builds, run with -Z macro-backtrace for more info)
```

This arises from trying to construct an expression like `<$foo as Foo>::Error::Corge(_)`, but seems to only be a syntactic problem, because the following alternative is allowed:

```rust
type FooError = <$foo as Foo>::Error;
FooError::Corge(_)
```

I'm not sure whether to suggest that the diagnostic should be changed or that this particular syntax should be allowed (I would think the second would be preferable, but is obviously a bigger change).
